posts.name: Kayla Blosser
posts.cooked:
TL;DR:

Hack Club is renting an island

It will be the first, and likely only, island hackathon in the world

It’s free + everyone is eligible for travel stipends

It will only happen if we hit 5,000 sign-ups

Sign up at https://shipwrecked.hackclub.com/24

A year ago, I had the crazy idea to run a hackathon on an island in the Boston Harbor. Today, we made it happen.

Yes, Hack Club (a nonprofit dedicated to getting tennagers coding) is renting a private island. Yes, we’re running a hackathon on it.

Introducing…

Shipwrecked , a Hack Club hackathon on an island!

On August 8-11, you and 130 other teenagers will gather on Cathleen Stone Island in the Massachusetts Bay for a once in a lifetime, 4-day story-based hackathon! As soon as you get there, you’ll all start working together to survive!

To get invited, you’ll complete…

The Bay:

Spend a total of 60 hours making 4 projects (~ 15 hours each) that you are really proud of.

Share them with the rest of the world and make at least one go viral! We’ll help you get there with workshops, online events, and more.

Get invited to Shipwrecked! (Travel stipends available, more information here)

In short:

Build 4 projects in The Bay and make them go viral - spend 60 hours making projects and you’ll get an invite to…

Go to #shipwrecked on the Hack Club Slack on August 8-11 - a hackathon on an island in the Boston Harbor!

Shipwrecked will start when we hit 5000 interested. Join now and learn more at shipwrecked.hackclub.com

PS: Join #shipwrecked on the Hack Club Slack to meet other hackers!

link_counts.title: A Home for High School Hackers – Hack Club

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
“Flown” to the island on a ferry boat, I guess…

FAQ

Drop-off and pick-up will happen at EDIC Pier in the Seaport District. The ferry will leave promptly one hour after the start of the event and will not wait for latecomers.

posts.name: MikLast
posts.cooked:
Hack Club has done a few things with FIRST already, including other hackathons and the “ Hack Club Bank ” thats meant to be a way to track a team finances.

I think point 2 is overselling it a little (Hawaii must of had at least one hackathon, right?) but it sounds pretty cool.

posts.name: Tyler Olds
posts.cooked:
I don’t think there’s any issue with this being posted on the surface here on CD .

I am a bit curious to the 130 teenagers on an island safety part, how they are collecting info from Teenagers on their website (the form says for teenagers under the age of 18) and the safety and security of these individuals  It took 4 clicks to get to their for Parents page and it wasn’t very intuitive on how to get there.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked: It may be legit, but this is giving me serious Fyre Festival vibes.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked: If I had received something like this at work, correct procedure would be to report it.  As a phish.
I’m curious why it requires 5,000 signups if only 130 people attend?

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: I don’t know what it is, but something about this makes me uncomfortable.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
It definitely is odd. I realistically don’t think it’s suspicious as Hack Club is a legitimate organization that works with minors and organizations as their core function so I’m sure they’re doing what they need to in order to be above board. However it definitely just is a weird thing to host.

Programming4907:

giving me serious Fyre Festival vibes.

I also immediately thought of this too. Funny enough, I swear I saw something about a Fyre festival 2

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
It seems like you have to be invited to Shipwrecked by completing a bunch of online challenges first.  I think the 5000 might be to kickoff the initial challenges.

From their FAQ:

Hack Club is committed to creating a safe and comfortable environment for students at our events. As with previous Hack Club events, All adults present (Hack Club staff and external contractors) have undergone rigorous background checks (both at the state and Federal level). We aim for a gender-balanced community and offer a safe space for all teenagers. We will have support available and a way for you and your child to contact us if needed. During the event, a toll-free staff helpline (+1 855-625-HACK) will be available 24/7 if you have any questions. Cathleen Stone Island has cell reception and Wi-Fi so you will be able to stay in contact with your child.
I agree. It’s just plain bizarre. Why are we flying 130 children out to an island to for a hackathon? It is so unnecessary it warrants valid suspicion.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Some people call me the Space Cowboy

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
I think it’s nowhere near as sketchy as it sounds. It’s a publicly accessible island in Boston Harbor, previously called (and still known by locals as) “ Thompson Island ”

It’s technically privately owned, making it technically a private island, but it’s used for all kinds of educational purposes and trips. (There are school field trips that go to Thompson Island, so it’s not like it’s a super-weird thing.)

Let me introduce you to the world of the game threads:

Where almost nothing is related to robotics Also, no idea if the tags were edited at first, but this is in the “other” category, which doesn’t need to be as related to robotics.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Clodsire:

Why are we flying 130 children out to an island to for a hackathon?

Must be making a modern remake of ‘Lord of the Flies’ was my first thought.

Leaving that point aside it’s definitely a neat marketing tactic that gets your attention.
